posts.cooked:
Summary

This thread is intended to help build constructive conversation about automated messaging (bots) in Signal. Or at least put it to rest with an official response.

This topic was created from the discussion found here.

Current Status - 21 Jun 2023

Automated messaging (bots) is prohibited by the TOS

The Signal Terms of Service (TOS) as of 21 Jun 2023

You will not use (or assist others in using) our Services in ways that: [‚Ä¶] (b) involve sending illegal or impermissible communications such as bulk messaging, auto-messaging, and auto-dialing.

What‚Äôs known‚Ä¶

  • Bots can be created and are being used: Forum Link.
  • I can personally confirm this is possible.
  • Some form of captcha challenge and/or throttling will occur if bot-like activity is detected

What‚Äôs assumed‚Ä¶

  • Signal doesn‚Äôt want this to happen, but can‚Äôt or won‚Äôt completely stop it - at least right now.

Can a solution be found for official acceptance?

What must be addressed to make this viable?

  • SPAM?
  • large message throughput?
  • meta data collection

How are risks currently mitigated?

  • captcha
  • throttling - presumably by message count?
  • what else is even possible?

Can enough criteria be created to allow Signal to allow a bot to officially function ‚Äúon the service‚Äù?

Can bots actually be prevented anyway?
If so how? Or will it always need to be a ‚Äúpromise‚Äù not to do so?

If they can‚Äôt be prevented, could not some reasonable rate limiting requirement be used for general detection? Perhaps even 10/min? Something just under what a human could actually achieve? Is that even sufficient?

Hopefully this starts something helpful. Help me add to the requirements and concerns.

link_counts.title: Signal >> Terms of Service & Privacy Policy

posts.name: Navid Zamani
posts.cooked:
As a programmer, to be frank, the ‚Äúwar against bots‚Äù is as futile and pointless and counter-productive as the ‚Äúwar against drugs‚Äù.

The only difference between a bot, and a person with a computer is‚Ä¶ a time delay. Programs are just ‚Äúcanned human behavior‚Äù. And that includes current machine learning (and is exactly why it isn‚Äôt AI).

I‚Äôve worked quite a bit on this ‚Äúproblem‚Äù, and the final conclusion is, that the core fallacy is to assume there‚Äôs anyone who isn‚Äôt a bot. Factually, you cannot ever tell if someone is a human, especially nowadays, where the faked intelligence of machine learning scams (like ChatGPT) and the real intelligence of certain humans clearly overlap. And it‚Äôs neither necessary nor beneficial to do so either. Besides, at what point does it become a bot anyway? Is a timed/delayed message a bot? Is my PC coming from standby in the morning, going online, and Signal Desktop then submitting a message, making it look like I was online then, a bot? Is a passive-thinking by-choice-not-a-person human, being instructed to copy-paste the word of its leader, a bot? Is my hand with its reflexes or my programmable keyboard a bot?

One is much better suited by designing the system in a way that empowers everyone to ‚Äúhave a bot‚Äù. Because the automation is the the only advantage of bots, and it‚Äôs only an advantage because it is made a taboo and not everyone is enabled to use that. When the whole point of a computer is automation.
When everybody has the advantage, ‚Ä¶ then nobody does.

And in general, automation of information processing is one of greatest inventions humanity ever had. Bigger than even the wheel. To then go and treat it stepmotherly, equals not enabling people to use almost a superpower that they already have available.
I‚Äôd go so far as to say that any software that isn‚Äôt designed with automation in mind is fundamentally mis-designed and at worst, harmful to humanity. Smartphones being the single biggest prime example.

Yeah, like with drugs, if you embrace it, at least you can control it. And drugs aren‚Äôt just bad on principle either. Otherwise pharmacies and half of practical medicine wouldn‚Äôt exist.

Bot? Legalize it!

P.S.: There is one other option, but you‚Äôre not gonna like it either:

If you take the scientific definition of existence and reality, where: 1. the definition of existence is that you can tell (e.g. measure it), because if not then what‚Äôs the point; and 2. reality is relative; then‚Ä¶
If you really want to be sure that who you are talking to is a human (or you can‚Äôt ever tell that it isn‚Äôt, which is the same thing), then you need a classical network of personal real-world (afk/offline) trust relationships. As in: You have to have met the person in, well, person, and, only there, established the authenticated channel of communiation. (And I‚Äôm going way beyond some automagic code on an automagic device, made by people you never met and might as well be bots, authenticating it, like Signal does. I mean the people themselves authenticating it all, keys, algorithms, hardware, down to making their own chips with their own machines made from scratch to prevent dopant-level hardware trojans [yes, that is a real thing].)
And any person you haven‚Äôt met but are chatting to, only being as real as the person you have met, via which you got to know that other person, says they are.
So obviously not suitable for ever verifying that random ‚Äúperson‚Äù (better say ‚Äúaccount‚Äù) on the Internet. Because, as I said: You never can. (Anyone claiming otherwise, can‚Äôt actually tell reality from delusion.)

I‚Äôd prefer that solution. Since all the hate of the Internet stems from humans only being able to have empathy for humans they can see as actual people. Which requires having actually met them, and staying well below Dunbar‚Äôs number. (In short: On the Internet, everyone‚Äôs a psychopath aka sociopath. [Yeah, according to the ICD, they‚Äôre really the same thing.] So the ‚Äúglobal village‚Äù is actually a toxic dystopia that will destroy humanity; as anyone can clearly see nowadays.)
posts.edit_reason: A post was merged in by Herohtar

posts.cooked:
A good way to add bots, if possible, while limiting spam is to make official bot accounts unable to create messaging channels/groups (so someone needs to add/message the bot for the bot to be used, perhaps deauthorized if safety number of a DM changes unless added again). These bots can also only be permitted to read/send messages (to avoid call spam) and have unique identifiers (not usernames, a random string unless officially supported by Signal) as opposed to mobile numbers. They can interact with the account through an encrypted API with a token associated to the bot account.

Maybe each bot can be associated to an account, so that there is some accountability for bots. It is an insecure channel and should be warned and treated as such. Users should be responsible with their use of bots, and those who make bots should be responsible for their use.

posts.name: Armando
posts.cooked:
I just waited for someone to bring this up, so here is my take on this:

  • Make a developer console for creating official bot applications.
  • Bots are clearly marked as bots.
  • Make an official API and help the community build solid frameworks for different programming languages. (Currently, everything is wrapped around the Signal-CLI, which isn‚Äôt the cleanest and most well-integrated solution.)
justsignal:

SPAM?

justsignal:

large message throughput?

Rate limiting. Allow ~ 1,000 credits/h for free, one request being 1-5 credits. If someone wants to make more powerful bots, they can buy credits cheaply (no profit intended). Most spammers won‚Äôt bother paying any money as it could identify them by their payment info. Also, there should be a Report Spam feature for bots, so if a handful of users report one within 24h, the bot can be disabled and the owner banned, not being able to make any other bots with his payment info.

justsignal:

meta data collection

If you mean that bots can read messages and save them externally, the app could warn users before starting a chat or adding them to groups. If you mean Signal would be able to collect more data, that wouldn‚Äôt necessarily be the case, because most bot server applications would run their own specced down version of Signal, that also uses end-to-end encryption, like the current Signal-CLI.

justsignal:

Can enough criteria be created to allow Signal to allow a bot to officially function ‚Äúon the service‚Äù?

Yes! As Signal shifts more towards a social media app, demand for features like this will grow. Some people might want to use Signal exclusively for simple private messaging, and that‚Äôs okay. But it‚Äôs important to keep in mind that most mainstream users will actually like these features and shift away from Telegram. The Signal community needs to be louder and more open to change in order to convince devs to build an official bot feature.

pseudonymous:

make official bot accounts unable to create messaging channels/groups

Sounds like a great idea! Signal clients can simply not show any message requests from bots that haven‚Äôt been added to Contacts before. Telegram does the same I think. You would need to hit Start or type /start to start a msg channel. If you wanna stop, you can hit Stop and Delete. For groups, bots will have to be added by admins and can then also message members privately. When the bot gets removed, the Contact also get deleted for everyone and the bot stops.

I just went down the ‚Äúare signal bots a thing‚Äù rabbit hole and found this thread. It would be awesome to continue building consensus for this use case.

I host a small handful of services for friends and family and have a need for a consolidated place that I can send messages to. The lack of official support for bots pushes people to the Discord‚Äôs and Slack‚Äôs of the world, but everyone I need to notify is already on Signal. When a more challenging aspect of being Signal user tends to be getting a critical mass of people to actually use it, it sucks to have to have to send people elsewhere for this kind of thing.

Have you considered using

github.com

GitHub - AsamK/signal-cli: signal-cli provides an unofficial commandline,...

signal-cli provides an unofficial commandline, JSON-RPC and dbus interface for the Signal messenger.

link_counts.title: GitHub - AsamK/signal-cli: signal-cli provides an unofficial commandline, JSON-RPC and dbus interface for the Signal messenger.

posts.cooked:
Yes I have considered that, as well as the signal-cli-rest-api project that uses it. I did not mean to imply there were not currently any options for posting to Signal programmatically, but to advocate for it being officially supported.

I have not taken a super deep look at either project, but for now I am less inclined to use them because of the Signal imposed constraint of having to acquire a phone number to register an account with, or having the posts just come from my own account.

Acknowledging up front this may be just a me thing, but I feel that the decision to require a phone number for registration is not dissimilar to the thinking that led many institutions in the US to use social security numbers as de-facto ID when SSN‚Äôs are not fit for that purpose. The result being rampant identity fraud. Outsourcing proof of identity to the traditional telecom apparatus at best just introduces a minimal amount of friction to the process.

But because I‚Äôm stubborn and opinionated it‚Äôs friction I‚Äôd rather not engage with.

link_counts.title: GitHub - bbernhard/signal-cli-rest-api: Dockerized Signal Messenger REST API

posts.cooked:
All understandable.

In case you were unaware, you could use signal-CLI as a linked device. In this case you would not need an additional phone number, but you would have the posts come from your own account.

This does, in fact, appear to be the go-to solution for creating many bots, but using it still appears to be in direct violation of the TOS (see original post). This is exactly why I started this topic as this cli utility works just fine

posts.name: Wyatt Childers
posts.cooked:
Threema has a broadcast service; it would be great if Signal had at least the ‚Äúone direction messaging for a group chat or user that opted into it‚Äù use case encapsulated.

That would handle things like outage notifications, announcements, and reminders.
